Mixed Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts and HZSM-5 (HZ5) have received attention as bifunctional catalysts that directly convert syngas into value-added aromatic monomers. However, both low selectivity of aromatics and severe deactivation remain challenges. Here we report a simple method for obtaining selective aromatics from syngas by tuning the distribution of hydrocarbon (HC) intermediates on K/FeMn. We prepared K/FeMn catalysts with a varying Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% to demonstrate the effect of the HC distribution as intermediates of aromatization on HZ5. The C6-C10 distribution was increased by addition of up to 60 wt% of Mn promoter due to the improved dispersion of Fe7C3 and alkyl insertion of MnO. At 340 °C under 20 bar, 97.2% CO conversion and 39.8% aromatics selectivity were achieved by using a physically mixed catalyst of K/FeMn with Mn/(Fe+Mn) 60 wt% and HZ5 with an optimization of the FTS-derived C6-C10 olefin yield as efficient intermediates in Syngas to Aromatics (STA). Graphical abstract Plausible scheme for FTS and STA reactions in this study. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Syngas to aromatics One-stage reaction Higher olefin Hydrocarbon distribution Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Attention on syngas utilization has been increased due to the abundant gas resources such as shale-gas, by-product gas, bio-gas, and coal-gasified gas [1–3]. However, as a result of the lack of an on-site utilization technology and the constraints in storage and transportation, large amounts of the produced and emitted gasses have been burned for gaining thermal energy or vented at many places, thereby contributing to global warming [4,5]. The FTS process can produce liquid fuels and valuable chemicals such as gasoline, diesel, ether, and light olefins from syngas [6–8]. Accordingly, FTS has been investigated as one of the promising technologies using syngas and research was accelerated by the decrease of gas prices with the shale-gas revolution. [9]. However, the FTS derived HCs widely distribute from C1 to C40+ following an Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) distribution and mainly contain paraffins, olefins, and naphthenes [10,11]. Upgrading steps are thus required to obtain high value-added chemicals in the FTS process, leading to an increase of the capital cost for additional facilities. Recently many groups have carried out research to overcome the ASF distribution and selectively produce the desired HCs [12,13]. Aromatics compounds are the most important chemical as a basic material in the chemical industry. In particular, BTEX (Benzene, Toluene, Ethylbenzene and Xylene) is a basic chemical used in various fields (benzene: synthesis of nylon, toluene: solvent or synthesis of dinitrotoluene, ethylbenzene: styrene monomer, xylene: synthesis of PET monomer) [14–17]. BTEX has been commercially produced by naphtha cracking. Also, AROMAX of CHEVRON and CYCLAR of UOP produce aromatics and hydrogen from light HCs [18]. However, problems with the raw material supply can be anticipated owing to a sharp increase in the price of oil price and this tendency has been maintained over the past decade. It is therefore necessary to diversify the raw material using low price feedstock such as gas resources (shale gas, associated gas, stranded gas, biogas and land fill gas from organic wastes, waste or coal gasification and steel mill gasses). Aromatic compounds from syngas are synthesized by cracking and dehydroaromatization of FTS-derived HC on solid acid sites in acidic catalysts such as HZ5. To increase aromatics selectivity, physically mixed catalysts, which contain metal for FTS and zeolites for aromatization, have been introduced in the manner of dual bed or single bed STA systems [19–22]. The single bed processes have been studied extensively due to the simplicity of the process [23,24]. Although the single bed STA process is simpler than the dual bed process, it is difficult to derive high conversion and aromatics selectivity simultaneously due to the different reaction conditions of FTS and aromatization. FTS reactions using iron-based catalysts are usually performed at ∼300 °C and the products are mainly composed of C2-C4 light olefins [7,24]. However, it is difficult to achieve the single bed STA with high yield aromatics because of differing optimum conditions, including temperature above 400 °C for the conversion of the light olefins to aromatics [25,26]. In recent years, Zhao et al. and Xu et al. published a combined iron catalyst with alkali treated HZ5, which showed high CO conversion (> 80%), aromatics selectivity (> 50%), and stability because of the moderate acid sites of HZ5 [27,28]. However, research on the effect of aromatics selectivity on the distribution of FTS-derived intermediates in STA is still insufficient. It has been expected that the shift of the FTS-derived product distribution with light olefin predominance to higher olefin will induce high aromatics yield due to the decrease of temperature required for dehydroaromatizaion. In the FTS using an iron catalyst, manganese is widely used as a promoter to overcome the ASF distribution. Many research groups reported that adding manganese to an iron catalyst can specify the HCs distribution due to electronic and structural effects [29,30]. It was also reported that a manganese promoter can increase the selectivity of C2-C4 or C5+ depending on the variation of the Mn/Fe ratio [31]. The aim of the present study is to identify the effect of the FTS derived HC distribution on the selectivity of produced aromatic compounds in a single bed reaction with physically mixed catalysts (FT catalyst + HZ5 catalyst) during the syngas conversion reaction. K/FeMn catalysts with varying Mn content were prepared by the co-precipitation method and the catalytic characteristics were investigated. Both FTS and STA were performed using K/FeMn with varying Mn content and the HC distributions of each reaction were compared to investigate the effect of the distribution of HCs produced by FTS on the aromatics selectivity in STA. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The K/Fe-Mn for FTS was prepared by the co-precipitation of metal precursors, followed by potassium impregnation. The metal and potassium precursors were Fe(NO3)3·9H2O (98.5%, Samchun), Mn(NO3)2·6H2O (98.0%, Samchun), and K2CO3 (99.5%, Samchun). The Fe-nitrate and Mn-nitrate solutions with a desired Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% (= 0 ∼ 100) were dissolved in water. The metal-nitrate solution was poured into a vigorously stirred K2CO3 solution for precipitation. The slurry obtained by co-precipitation was subjected to filtrations and washing cycles. The catalyst cake was then dried in air at 110 °C overnight and calcined at 450 °C for 4 h. The obtained product was impregnated with K2CO3 using the incipient wetness technique. Drying and calcination were subsequently carried out under the same conditions. After secondary calcination, the catalysts were sieved to 425∼600 µm. The synthesized K/FeMn catalysts were denoted as KFxM, where x is the weight percentage of Mn/(Fe+Mn). The catalysts for aromatization were obtained by calcination of NH4 +-ZSM5 (Zeolyst, zeolite powder with a Si/Al molar ratio of 15, 40, and 140) under flowing air at 550 °C for 5 h. The acid catalysts were sieved to 425∼600 µm after pelletizing. The obtained catalysts were denoted as HZ5(15), HZ5(40), and HZ5(140) according to the Si/Al molar ratio. 2.2 Catalytic reaction and product analysis The FTS and STA reactions were conducted in a fixed-bed single reactor made of 1/2 inch 304 stainless steel tubing. In the case of FTS reactions, the K/FeMn catalyst (0.3 g, 425 ∼ 600 µm) with varying Mn content diluted with α-alumina balls (0.6 g) was loaded into the reactor. The K/FeMn catalyst physically mixed with the same size HZ5 (0.6 g) was used in the STA reactions with varying conditions. The diluent was excluded in the STA reactions. Feed gas for the FTS reaction was a balanced syngas consisting of CO/H2/Ar = 31/62/7 molar ratio. The catalysts were reduced in situ using the syngas for 5 h at 300 °C under 1 bar. The conditions of the FTS reaction were fixed at 340 °C, 20 bar, and SV= 10,000 ml/gcat·h because they showed the highest selectivity of aromatics in the STA results. The effluent from the reactor was periodically injected into two serially on-line gas chromatographs (GC). The 1st GC (YOUNGLIN Acme 6000) calculated the CO conversion and C1-C4 HCs selectivity (C-mol%) using Ar and He as internal standards and carrier gasses, respectively. Ar, CO2, CO, and CH4 were analyzed with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) equipped with a packed column (Carboxen 1000, SUPELCO), and C1–C4 HCs were analyzed with an FID equipped with a capillary column (PLOT/Q, HP). The 2nd GC (SHIMADZU 2010 plus) was operated to analyze and calculate the selectivity (C-mol%) of middle distillates such as BTEX, alkyl aromatics, and C5+ HCs with a FID equipped with a capillary column (Rtx®−100-DHA, RESTEK) and He was used as a carrier gas. The reactor and GC analysis system is schematically presented in Fig. S1. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The surface morphology of the prepared catalysts was investigated by using an ultra-high resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (UHR FE-SEM, Hitachi, S-5500) at the Korea Basic Science Institute (KBSI) in Jeonju, South Korea. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured to obtain information about the pore structure of the prepared catalysts. Before the measurements, samples were degassed at 350 °C for 4 h, and then nitrogen adsorption was performed at -196 °C using a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) apparatus (Micromeritics ASAP 2020) to determine the specific surface areas, total pore volumes, and pore size distributions. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed at room temperature in the 2Θ range from 5° to 80° using a Rigaku Ultima-IV diffractometer equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54 Å) radiation (40 kV, 40 mA). An inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometer (ICP-AES) analysis of the prepared catalysts was carried out using an iCAP 6500 (Thermo Scientific) to measure the bulk metal content. The RF power, frequency, and plasma gas were 1350 W, 27.12 MHz, and Ar = 12 L/min, respectively. To investigate the elements present and the bonding state in the samples, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the samples were obtained using an AXIS NOVA (KRATOS Corporation, England). Al Kα (1485.6 eV) was used as the X-ray source with a 15 keV anode voltage and a 10 mA filament current. All samples were treated at 10−9 ∼ 10−8 torr to remove impurities. The survey spectra and a high resolution analysis were obtained at a 160 eV and 40 eV pass energy, respectively. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) measurements were conducted with an AutoChem II 2920 fully automatic physical/chemical adsorption analyzer equipped with a TCD detector. First, 100 mg of as-prepared samples was loaded and pretreated with Ar at 200 °C for 1 h to remove the absorbers. After cooling down to room temperature, 10% H2/Ar or 10% CO/He was injected to analyze H2-TPR or CO-TPR, respectively. The samples were heated to 700 °C at a ramp of 10 °C/min in an atmosphere of reduction gas. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) profiles of the catalysts after the reaction were obtained using a TA Instrument SDT Q600 V20.5 Build. The samples were heated under an air flow of 100 mL/min to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic performance of K/FeMn catalysts in the FTS reaction FTS was carried out using syngas with H2/CO = 2 and the product distributions according to the catalysts with varying Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% were investigated. Fig. 1 (a) shows the CO conversion of the K/FeMn catalysts. The initial CO conversion of the FT catalysts was high at 95% and gradually decreased during 40 h-on stream in the case of Mn content up to 20 wt%. The FT catalysts with Mn content over 40 wt% showed a sharp decrease of CO conversion at a certain TOS. The deactivation rate was increased with increasing the Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% and the catalyst without Fe showed no activity in FTS. The acceleration of catalytic deactivation was attributed to an increase of the coking rate due to a decrease in iron content as an active phase of the FTS. The distributions of FTS-produced HCs are presented in Fig. 1(b). The HC distribution of the catalyst without Mn decreased with increasing carbon number from C3 to C15+, which followed the ASF plot [32]. The C1-C4 selectivity was decreased while the C5-C9 selectivity was increased with increasing Mn content up to 60 wt% in the catalyst. The maximum peak of the HC distributions hence was shifted to a higher carbon number. In the case of Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% = 80, the C5-C10 distribution decreased while the C10+ distribution significantly increased. Fig. 1(c) shows the FTS-derived HC distribution of the KF60M catalyst. The center of distribution hump was C5 and the distribution gradually decreased with an increasing carbon number. The FTS-derived HCs consisted of paraffins, olefins, naphthenes, aromatics, etc. The olefins were dominant in the distribution and the other components were below 2% at each carbon number. In this study, the HCs after FTS of the Mn promoted catalysts similarly consisted with each other and are presented in Fig. S2. The aliphatic HC selectivities according to each range are shown in Fig. 1(d). The total aliphatic HC selectivity was increased by the addition of up to 60 wt% Mn promoter and thereafter decreased. With increasing Mn content, the selectivity of C6-C10 olefin was increased while the selectivity of C2-C5 was decreased. In the results of the Mn promoted catalyst, KF80M showed the lowest C2-C5 and the highest C6-C10 olefin selectivity. In addition, the selectivity of C11+ olefins was particularly higher than that of the other Mn added catalysts. Eventually, the addition of Mn promoter on the iron-based catalyst enhanced the olefin selectivity and the chain propagation rate of HCs [33]. Also, it can be inferred that the catalytic stability of Fe-Mn catalysts decreased with an increasing Mn ratio because of the deposition of higher olefins on active sites [34–36]. However, the olefin selectivities did not show a significant change during 40 h-on stream and were unrelated to the profiles of CO conversion, as presented in Fig. S3(a). The detailed conversion and HC selectivity are presented in Table 1 . 3.2 Catalytic performance of K/FeMn with HZ5 catalysts in the STA reaction STA reactions were carried out according to catalysts with varying Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% under the same conditions as employed for FTS. The K/FeMn catalysts were physically mixed with the same size HZ5. Fig. 2 (a) shows the CO conversion of the K/FeMn + HZ5 catalysts. The CO conversion of all catalysts was very high at above 95% and was maintained over 40 h-on stream without deactivation, with the exception of KF80M. The CO conversion of KF80M gradually decreased during 40 h on stream, which is significantly different from the FTS results. The distributions of HCs produced by the STA reaction are shown in Fig. 2(b). In the case of the distribution of the STA products, it was separated with two peaks in the HC distribution, which appeared at C2-C5 and C6-C10, respectively. The CH4 selectivity was higher than that in the FTS results except for the HC distribution of KF80M because of cracking on the acid sites of HZ5. And also, CH4 selectivity was slightly decreased with increasing Mn(Fe+Mn) wt%. The second peak at C6-C10 was enhanced with increasing Mn content up to 60 wt%. This indicates that the BTEX selectivity was increased. The HC selectivities above C11 were very low (below 2%). Fig. 2(c) shows the HC distribution of the STA reaction using KF60M with HZ5. The STA product mainly consisted of CH4, C2-C4 paraffins, and aromatics. This indicates that the FTS produced intermediates were converted to light paraffins and aromatics by the acid sites on HZ5. Consequently, the addition of HZ5 catalyst to FTS catalyst improved the STA reaction stability and significantly increased the aromatics selectivity because the acid sites of HZ5 suppressed the production of long chain HCs during syngas conversion [37]. The HC distributions of all catalysts after STA were almost the same as that in Fig. 2(c) and the distributions are presented in Fig. S4. The aromatics selectivity at 2 and 38 h-on stream presented in Fig. 2(d) (and Table S1) increased with increasing Mn content up to 60 wt%. The aromatics selectivity was highest at 39.8% for the case of Mn(Fe+Mn) wt% = 60 and then significantly decreased at Mn(Fe+Mn) wt% = 80. The highest aromatics selectivity in the STA reaction was obtained using the KF60M catalyst, which showed the highest C6-C10 olefin selectivity with low C11+ HC selectivity in the FTS reaction. Generally, the dehydroaromatization reactivity of HC intermediates on acid catalysts such as zeolites becomes high with an increasing carbon number. Also, olefins show higher dehydroaromatization reactivity than that of paraffins [38,39]. Therefore, it can be suggested that the production of a large amount of middle distillate (C6-C10) olefins in FTS helps to obtain more aromatic compounds in STA. In the FTS results, as presented in Fig. 1(d), KF80M showed high total olefin selectivity (63.6%) and the highest C11+ olefin selectivity (6.2%) among the Mn promoted catalysts. The C11+HCs prevent the adsorption of light HCs into the pores of HZ5 and are deposited on the catalyst surface. As a result, although the KF80M catalyst showed high olefin selectivity, the aromatics selectivity was lowest at 34.2% among the Mn promoted catalysts. The aromatics selectivities of 38 h-on stream were significantly decreased by deactivation of HZ5. It is well known that deactivation of zeolite is caused by carbon deposition on acid sites. In particular, the BTEX selectivity dramatically decreased while the C9+aromatics selectivity slightly increased. It can be inferred that the dealkylation rate decreased because the strong acid sites were preferentially deactivated by carbon deposition [24]. The aromatics selectivities depending on time in stream are presented in Fig. S3(b). Also, the detailed conversion and HC selectivity are presented in Table 2 . The optimum STA conditions using KF60M were investigated with varying temperature (Fig. S5), pressure (Fig. S6), and Si/Al ratio (Fig. S7). The CO conversions were very high (about 97%) and steady during 40 h-in stream at all temperatures. As shown in Fig. S5, the aromatics selectivity in STA significantly increased with increasing temperature up to 340 °C and then decreased. The optimal STA reaction temperature was 340 °C and the light HC selectivity increased due to the increase of cracking rates at higher temperature [24]. At all temperatures, the aromatics selectivities significantly decreased while on stream due to the deactivation of HZ5 by carbon deposition. In Fig. S6, the initial CO conversion at varying pressure was very high at about 97% and this level was maintained during 40 h-on stream, except for the result at 10 bar. The KF60M catalyst was quickly deactivated during 40 h-on stream at 10 bar. It can be inferred that carbon deposition was induced due to the low chain propagation and high methanation rate [7]. The aromatics selectivity was highest at 20 bar and it significantly decreased while on stream. Although the dehydroaromatization reaction preferentially occurs at low pressure, the result of the STA reaction at 10 bar showed low aromatic selectivity because unsuitable HC intermediates were produced due to the low chain propagation rate [24]. The CO conversions were high and steady in the STA reaction with a varying Si/Al ratio of HZ5 (in Fig. S7). In general, the acidity of HZ5 increased with a decreasing Si/Al ratio. The aromatics selectivity was highest in the STA result using HZ5(15) and decreased with an increasing Si/Al ratio. In conclusion, the optimum conditions for the STA reaction in this study were 340 °C, 20 bar, and the use of KF60Mn with HZ5(15). 4 Discussion 4.1 Characterization of prepared catalysts 4.1.1 Surface morphology, textual properties and pore structure To investigate the change of surface morphology according to the Mn content, the UHR FE-SEM images and particle size distribution are presented in Fig. 3 (a) and (b), respectively. The catalyst without Mn presents a grain shape with average particle size of 38.3 nm (Fig. S8(a)). With increasing Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt%, the surface morphology changed from a grain shape to aggregates and the particle size was significantly decreased to about 21 nm (Fig. S8(f)). It can be inferred that the dispersion of iron species was increased by the addition of Mn promoter [31,40,41]. The relative particle size and Fe2O3 crystallite size of prepared K/FeMn catalysts are showed in Table S2. The relative crystallite size of Fe2O3 was decreased with increasing Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% and it was well matched with relative particle size [42]. The N2 isotherms of the prepared catalysts are plotted in Fig. 3(c) to assess the effect of the Mn promoter content on the pore structure. The N2 isotherms for fresh catalysts are typically type-IV curves according to the IUPAC classification and hysteresis loops were observed for all samples. The type-IV isotherm with hysteresis is obtained when the pore width was greater than ∼ 4 nm at -196 °C [43]. It thus can be inferred that the prepared catalysts have a mesoporous structure with pore width over 4 nm. With an increase of Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% to 60, the quantity of N2 adsorption increased and the closure point of the hysteresis loop shifted to a lower P/P0. It is suggested that the surface area was increased and the pore width was decreased due to the increase of Fe dispersion [43,44]. The results are consistent with the pore size distribution presented in Fig. 1(d) and specific information in Table 3 . The pore structure changes are caused by the increased dispersion of iron species due to the addition of Mn promoter. 4.1.2 Crystal phase of prepared catalysts The crystal phase of fresh and reduced catalysts was examined by a XRD analysis. Fig. 4 (a) shows the XRD patterns of fresh catalysts prepared with different Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt%. The XRD pattern of the KF catalyst indicated that the sample has high purity and a single phase of hematite (a-Fe2O3, JCPDS 33-0664, 2Ɵ = 24.1°, 33.1°, 35.6°, 40.8°, 49.4°, 54.0 o, 57.5 o, 62. o and 63.9°). The intensity of the hematite peaks at 2Ɵ = 33.5° and 36.0° decreased with increasing Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt%. It can be inferred that the dispersion rate of iron increased with increasing Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% [31,45]. The sample (K100M) without iron showed peaks at 2Ɵ = 23.1, 33.0, 38.3, 45.2, 49.3, 55.2, 60.6, 64.2, 56.8, and 67.5° (JCPDS 41–1442) indicating Mn2O3. It also showed peaks at 2Ɵ = 12.6°, 17.8°, 28.5°, 37.3°, 41.8°, 49.7°, and 60.0° (JCPDS 44–0141), indicating MnO2 [46]. The peaks of Mn2O3 and MnO2 were appeared and the intensity increased with manganese content. It can be indicated that the iron and manganese species were well dispersed in the bulk catalyst depending on the increase of Mn addition [31,45]. Also, it was not showed that iron manganese oxide as a precursor of Fe-Mn alloy in all patterns. The reduced samples were prepared by reduction at 300 °C for 5 h with syngas (H2/CO = 2). After reduction, the samples were directly dipped in n-octane for 24 h followed by filtering to prevent the oxidation of the reduced catalysts. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts are presented in Fig. 4(b). The pattern of the KF catalyst showed that it is mainly composed of Fe7C3 (JCPDS-17–0333) and metallic Fe (JCPDS 006–0696, 2Ɵ = 45°) after reduction [31,47]. The Fe7C3 and metallic Fe peaks decreased with increasing Mn content. In the case of the catalysts with Mn, Fe3O4 (JCPDS 65-3107) and MnO (JCPDS 07-0230) peaks appeared, and the peak intensity increased with increasing Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% [31,48]. It was not showed the phases of Fe-Mn alloys such as FeMnOx and FeMnCx. These results suggest that the Mn promoter improved the dispersion of Fe active metal as a structural promoter, and it was considered that the active site of the prepared K/FeMn catalyst is Fe7C3. 4.1.3 Reduction and carburization behavior of catalysts The reduction behavior of the catalysts was investigated by H2-TPR and the results are presented in Fig. 5 (a). Two reduction peaks were observed in the H2-TPR curve of the catalyst without Mn (KF). The peaks at around 330 and 550 °C are associated with the reduction of Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 and Fe3O4 → Fe, respectively [45,49]. In the case of the curve of catalyst without Fe (K100M), peaks appeared at around 223 °C and 370 °C, which are respectively associated with reduction of MnO2 → Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 → MnO [45,49]. In the H2-TPR curves of the Mn added catalysts, the first reduction peak of Fe species was not clearly distinguished from the second reduction peak of Mn due to the decreased intensity, and the second reduction peak of Fe species was shifted to lower temperature with increasing Mn content. With an increase of Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% to 60, the reduction peak of MnO2 appeared and shifted to lower temperature. In addition, the intensity and sharpness increased. It can be suggested that the Mn promoter improved the dispersion of Fe active metal as a spacer and reduced the temperature of H2 reduction due to the increased surface area. Fig. 5(b) shows the CO-TPR curves of the prepared samples. Two broad peaks were observed in all curves of CO-TPR. The first peak below 270 °C is associated with the reduction of (Fe, Mn)2O3 → (Fe, Mn)3O4. The second peak above 270 °C is known to be assignable to the reduction of Fe species and the formation of iron-carbides [45,49]. With an increase of Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% to 60, the first peak was shifted to low temperature. By the addition of Mn, the second peak was widened because iron carburization and Mn3O4 reduction peaks merged. With an increase of Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% to 60, the second peak was shifted to low temperature and the intensity was increased. It can be inferred that the addition of Mn to the Fe-based catalyst enhances the reducibility and carburization ability because the H2 and CO contact surface increased due to the increase of Fe and Mn dispersion according to the spacer effect [45,49]. 4.1.4 XPS analysis of fresh catalyst The chemical states of catalyst surface were investigated by XPS analysis. The surface (from XPS) and bulk (from ICP) Mn/(Fe+Mn)% of fresh K/FeMn catalysts are showed in Table 3. The bulk Mn ratio calculated from ICP analysis indicates that the K/FeMn catalysts were well prepared as we expected. The surface/Bulk ratio calculated from ICP and XPS results indicates that the Mn ratio on the catalyst surface is larger than that in the bulk and increase with Mn/(Fe+Mn)% up to 40 wt% in step of catalyst preparation [49]. However, it is considered that the effect of the surface/bulk ratio of the K/FeMn catalyst on HC distribution is not significant in this study. Fig. 6 (a) shows the survey spectra of fresh catalysts. Fe 2p, Mn 2p, O 1s, K 2p, and C 1s signals were detected in the spectra of the fresh catalysts. The Mn 2p peak appeared in the Mn promoted catalysts and Fe 2p peaks were undetected in K100M. This indicates that the Mn promoter was incorporated well into the co-precipitated catalysts. The Fe 2p spectrum of the fresh catalyst is shown in Fig. 6(b). Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2 peaks were detected at 720.9 and 707.6 eV, respectively, with satellite peaks of Fe3+at 729.5 and 715.7 eV [31,40,48]. Also, no distinct peaks from Fe0 and Fe2+ were observed. Therefore, the observation of peaks in Fe 2p indicates that the iron species of the prepared catalysts is only Fe2O3 phase. The intensity of Fe 2p peaks decreased with increasing Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt.% in the catalyst due to the decrease of Fe content. Meanwhile, there was no clear chemical shift of the peaks depending on the Mn content. The Mn 2p spectrum is presented in Fig. 6(c). Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p2/3 were observed at 650.7 and 638.8 eV in the spectrum [31,40,48]. The intensity of the peaks in the Mn 2p spectrum increased with increasing Mn content, while a chemical shift of the binding energy was not clearly seen in this investigation. Mn 3 s peak splitting has been used to distinguish Mn oxidation states because the bonding energy of Mn2+, Mn3+, and Mn4+are almost the same [31]. As shown in Fig 6(d), the Mn 3s peak has two split components due to the coupling of non-ionized 3 s electrons with 3d valence band electrons, and hence the Mn oxidation state can be distinguished by ΔE of the split peaks. ΔE of MnO (Mn2+), Mn2O3 (Mn3+), and MnO2 (Mn4+) are generally known as ≈ 6.0, ≥ 5.3, and ≈ 4.7 eV, respectively [31,50,51]. The split peaks appeared in all spectra except for 1K100Fe and the oxidation states were inferred as being Mn4+ dominant because of ΔE ≈ 5.0 eV. Ultimately, it can be inferred that there was no electron transfer from Mn to iron and the spacer influenced the distribution of active sites. 4.1.5 Characterization of spent K/FeMn catalysts The crystal phase of spent catalysts was examined by a XRD analysis and the results are shown in Fig. 7 (a). The XRD patterns of the spent catalyst without Mn in FTS (in Fig. 7(a)) indicated that the sample was composed of Fe3O4 (JCPDS-65-3107) and Fe7C3 (JCPDS-17-0333) [31,52]. The intensity of magnetite and Fe7C3 peaks decreased with increasing Mn content and it can be deduced that the dispersion of iron species increased with Mn addition [43–45]. The analysis results of the spent Fe-catalyst were well matched with the BET and XRD results of fresh catalysts. The MnO and Mn(CO3) peaks appeared in the XRD patterns of the Mn-added catalysts and the intensity increased with Mn content. As shown in the XRD patterns of the reduced (Fig. 4(b)) and spent (Figs. 7(a) and S9) catalyst, MnO serve as a CO activation site by forming Mn(CO3) (JCPDS card No. 44-1472) [53] . The activated CO molecule was then inserted into the carbon chain, which propagated on Fe-carbide [54]. Methane formation was suppressed and the chain length was increased due to the insertion of alkyl species by MnO. The XRD pattern of the spent catalysts in the STA reaction was similar with that of the FTS spent catalyst (Fig. S9). Fig. 7(b) and (c) show the TGA profiles of spent K/FeMn catalysts in the FTS and STA reactions, respectively. In the TGA profiles in Fig. 7(b), the weight of the samples slightly increased up to 200 °C and then dramatically decreased with increasing temperature. Weight losses were observed over 200 °C because of oxidation of deposited carbonaceous species such as carbides and coke. However, separation of the oxidation step, which was observed in the TGA profiles, is difficult. As seem in Fig. 7(d), it was clear that the weight loss by oxidation of deposited carbonaceous species increased with increasing Mn content on the K/FeMn catalyst. It can be deduced that the carbon deposition increased because the higher olefins, which is are important precursor of coke, increased with increasing Mn content [34–36]. However, relatively decreased weight loss occurred at Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt.% = 80 in FTS because of rapid deactivation of the catalyst. The TGA profiles of the spent catalyst in the STA reaction are presented in Fig. 7(c) and (d). The weight of the samples slightly increased due to oxidation of the catalyst and then dramatically decreased with increasing temperature by burn-off of deposited carbon. The weight loss profile can be divided into three sections of 260 ∼ 310 °C, 310 ∼ 320 °C, and 420 °C ∼. The first weight loss was due to evaporation of the remaining HCs that were derived by FTS. The second and third sections of weight loss were caused by oxidation of light coke and hard coke, respectively [7,36]. The TGA profiles of the spent catalyst in the STA reaction showed different shapes from those of the catalysts used for FTS. It can be deduced that the shape difference of the TGA profiles is due to the changing product distribution by zeolite mixing. Higher aromatics selectivity of the catalyst showed, the more clearly divided section of the TGA profile. Therefore, it can be inferred that the light coke (poly-substituted mono-aromatics) and hard coke (poly-aromatic compounds) of spent catalysts in the STA reactions were due to the aromatics that were deposited on HZ5 [55]. The weight loss of the spent catalysts in STA (Fig. 7(d)) was significantly lower than that of the catalysts used for FTS and increased with increasing Mn content. In the FTS reaction, longer chain olefins were produced by insertion of alkyl species on MnO and affected as coke precursors and an intermediate of aromatics [54]. The amount of carbon deposition consequently increased with Mn content due to the increased selectivity of the longer chain olefins. Also, it can be deduced that the spent catalysts in STA showed lower weight loss than the catalysts used for FTS because the HC intermediates after FTS were directly converted to aromatics and light paraffins on the HZ5 catalyst before being deposited as coke. The difference in the K/FeMn catalyst stability with or without HZ5 mixing (Figs. 5(a) and 6(a)) was due to the difference in the amount of carbon deposition. The KF60M + HZ5 catalysts in the STA reaction achieved high aromatic productivity and maintained high CO conversion by producing higher olefins and direct conversion preventing carbon deposition. 4.1.6 Plausible scheme of STA using K/FeMn with HZ5 A plausible scheme for the FTS and STA reactions in this study is presented in Fig. 8 . The KF catalyst without Mn produced light HC dominant products, which require high dehydrogenation energy for aromatization. Because of the space limitation of the zeolite channels, only the light HCs of C2–C5 can be well adsorbed in the channels. Aromatization of adsorbed light HCs generally entails oligomerization, cracking, hydrogen transfer, and cyclization steps, and these reactions mainly proceed on Brønsted acid sites. In particular, the aromatization of light HCs generally occurs on strong acid sites and high temperature [24,56]. In this study, the Mn promoter improved the distribution of middle distillates (C6-C10) due to the increase of Fe7C3 dispersion by acting as a spacer and alkyl insertion by MnO. The dehydrogenation energy of higher olefins is comparatively lower than that of light paraffins. The C6-C10 intermediates were easily converted to C6-C10 aromatics through dehydroaromatization, which requires lower dehydrogenation energy than the step reaction of light HCs [38,39]. Ultimately, the well dispersed catalysts consisting of Fe7C3 with MnO produced higher olefins and the distribution of FTS-derived HCs as the intermediates played a key role to achieve a high yield of aromatics. 5 Conclusion The effect of FTS-derived HC intermediates distribution on the yield of aromatic compounds was investigated in a single step STA reaction with physically mixed bifunctional catalysts (FT catalyst + HZ5 catalyst). K/FeMn catalysts were prepared with varying Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt.% and the ratio of C6-C10 hydrocabons in FTS-derived intermediates was increased by the addition of Mn promoter due to the improved dispersion of Fe7C3 and alkyl insertion of MnO [45,49,53]. K/FeMn catalysts with varying Mn content were prepared by a co-precipitation method and their catalytic characteristics were investigated. FTS and STA reactions were performed using K/FeMn with varying Mn content and the HC distributions of each reaction were compared to investigate the effect of the distribution of HCs produced by FTS on aromatics selectivity in STA. The C6-C10 intermediates mainly produced on K/FeMn in FTS were easily converted to C6-C10 aromatics through dehydroaromatization on HZ5 because the dehydrogenation energy of higher olefins is comparatively lower than that of light HCs [38,39]. At 340 oC and pressure under 20 bar, 97.2% CO conversion and 39.8% aromatics selectivity were achieved in the STA reaction using a physically mixed bifunctional catalyst of K/FeMn with Mn/(Fe+Mn) = 60 wt.% and HZ5. Conclusionally, well dispersed catalysts consisting of Fe7C3 with MnO after Mn promotion enabled to produce more C6-C10 intermediates during FTS and the dominantly produced long chain intermediates played a key role to achieve high yield of aromatics on HZ5 in STA. coredata.dc:description: Mixed Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) catalysts and HZSM-5 (HZ5) have received attention as bifunctional catalysts that directly convert syngas into value-added aromatic monomers. However, both low selectivity of aromatics and severe deactivation remain challenges. Here we report a simple method for obtaining selective aromatics from syngas by tuning the distribution of hydrocarbon (HC) intermediates on K/FeMn. We prepared K/FeMn catalysts with a varying Mn/(Fe+Mn) wt% to demonstrate the effect of the HC distribution as intermediates of aromatization on HZ5. The C6-C10 distribution was increased by addition of up to 60 wt% of Mn promoter due to the improved dispersion of Fe7C3 and alkyl insertion of MnO. At 340 °C under 20 bar, 97.2% CO conversion and 39.8% aromatics selectivity were achieved by using a physically mixed catalyst of K/FeMn with Mn/(Fe+Mn) 60 wt% and HZ5 with an optimization of the FTS-derived C6-C10 olefin yield as efficient intermediates in Syngas to Aromatics (STA).
coredata.dc:title: Enhancing selectivity of aromatics in direct conversion of syngas over K/FeMn and HZSM-5 bifunctional catalysts
